There were several reasons for the outbreak of the American Revolution, all revolving around one central theme. That theme was the attempt by the British aristocracy to exert control over the American colonies. Prior to ~1763, for over 100 years, the colonies had enjoyed a form of 'benign neglect'. London had essentially ignored the colonies and the colonists had liked the relationship, establishing their own local governments. Several English (before the Act of Union, so they were English not British) governments tried to change the situation but the chaos that was the English political system in the 17th century prevented that. Charles I fell just before trying to establish control over the colonies; the same was true of Oliver Cromwell and James II (?, the one that fell in the Glorious Revolution). 
 
 Starting around 1763, King George III launched his own initiative designed to bend the colonies to London's authority. By this point, the colonists' luck had run out and George III was able to start the program without a political collapse back home. The colonists, seeing a policy that went against over a century of tradition, were worried. Some of that fear was lessened by the American popular support of the monarchy. The Empire's victory in the Seven Years' War/French and Indian War, however, meant that the colonies no longer faced the threat of the French from Canada, reducing the need for protection from Great Britain. Furthermore, One Parlamentary Act after another slowly eroded at the support of the monarchy and the mother country. 
 
 This erosion was only partly due to taxation. Yes, the colonists were quite angry over the lack of representation. The areas that became the heart of the early Revolution (particularly New England) enjoyed a long history of representative government and local town meetings. These men were perfectly willing to pay taxes (many small villages paid vast sums to arm themselves in defense of the right to avoid a small tax from Great Britain, not exactly a monetarily based argument), but they wanted to be involved in the decision making process. Or, more accurately, they wanted to tax themselves. There were other sources of discontent. Many colonists feared that London would impose an official Anglican Church on the colonies (there were recommendations to do so). The Currency Act was blamed for the collapse in the colonial economy in the 1760s. The garrisoning of troops in seaport cities (rather than the frontier where they were needed) caused many conspiracy-minded Americans to ponder why, and none of the answers were innocent. This interference or imagined interference drove many colonials to support the Whig movement or end open support for the Tories.
